children.name: report
children.definition: information that sth has happened, which may or may not be true : báo cáo, phản ánh
examples: report of
Police received reports of a bomb threat at the airport at 11:28 p.m.
Government officials have denied reports of rebel advances.
The government has promised to investigate reports of police corruption.
report that
a report that he had been killed

children.name: receive a report
examples: Amnesty has received repeated reports of violation of detention procedures.

children.name: have a report
children.definition: receive one
examples: The police say they had reports of a gang shooting in East London.

children.name: confirm a report
examples: A spokesman refused to confirm reports that the aircraft had previously suffered an engine fire.

children.name: deny a report
examples: Government officials have denied reports of rebel advances.

children.name: dismiss a report
children.definition: refuse to consider it because you believe it is not true
examples: A Treasury official yesterday dismissed the reports as ‘pure speculation’.

children.name: an unconfirmed report
children.definition: not yet supported by official information
examples: There are unconfirmed reports that up to 2,000 people have been killed.

children.name: an eyewitness/first-hand report
children.definition: from someone who saw what happened
examples: Some were beaten and tortured according to first-hand reports from former prisoners.

children.name: a reliable report
examples: On Sunday there were reliable reports of a group of whales off the Devon coast.

children.name: an unofficial report
examples: According to unofficial reports, the president had talks with Palestinian leaders.

children.name: conflicting reports
children.definition: reports saying very different things
examples: Conflicting reports continued to emerge from the area.

children.name: a misleading report
children.definition: likely to make you believe something that is not true
examples: This isn’t the first time the industry has published misleading reports based on incomplete data.

children.name: rumour
children.definition: UK /rumorUSS  information which is passed from one person to another and which may or may not be true, especially information about people’s private lives or about sth that a government, company etc has done or is planning to do: tin đồn, lời đồn đoán
examples: COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say'a rumour spreads out'. Saya rumour spreads.

children.name: a rumour spreads
examples: A rumour spread that he had been killed.

children.name: a rumour goes around
children.definition: alsoa rumour circulatesformal
examples: (= a rumour is passed among people )There are a lot of rumors going around that they’re going to sell the company.|Not long afterwards, ugly rumours began to circulate.

children.name: rumour has it
children.definition: it is being said
examples: Rumour has it that they plan to get married.

children.name: rumours fly around
children.definition: are talked about by a lot of people
examples: There were wild rumours flying around the office on Wednesday.

children.name: hear a rumour
examples: I heard a rumour that she was leaving.

children.name: spread a rumour
examples: Someone has been spreading rumours about us.

children.name: deny a rumour
examples: He is denying rumors that he plans to drop out of the race.

children.name: confirm a rumour
children.definition: say that it is true
examples: The actor’s agent would not confirm the rumour.

children.name: false/unfounded
examples: He says that the rumours are completely unfounded.|False rumors began to spread that troops were massing on the border.

children.name: rumours are rife
children.definition: are talked about by a lot of people
examples: Rumours were rife that the band had refused to play.

children.name: a widespread rumour
examples: The arrests followed widespread rumours of police corruption.

children.name: a persistent rumour
children.definition: one that keeps being repeated for a long time
examples: Despite persistent rumours of an affair, his wife stood by him.

children.name: a strong rumour
children.definition: a rumour that is likely to be true
examples: There is a strong rumour that the government is planning to drop the idea.

children.name: a wild rumour
children.definition: one that is completely untrue
examples: It has been a week of wild rumour and exaggeration.

children.name: a malicious rumour
children.definition: a false one that someone spreads to make trouble
examples: The claims were dismissed by the government as ‘malicious rumours’.

children.name: an ugly/nasty rumour
children.definition: a rumour about something bad
examples: Ugly rumours persisted that there had been a cover-up.

children.name: an unsubstantiated rumour
children.definition: one that has not been proved to be true
examples: These are only unsubstantiated rumours.

children.name: a scurrilous rumourformal
children.definition: a damaging and false rumour
examples: Journalists spread scurrilous rumours about the school.

children.name: wild rumours
children.definition: rumours that are not likely to be true
examples: This led to wild rumours of American involvement in the attack.

children.name: rumour about/of
examples: I’ve heard all sorts of rumours about him and his secretary.

children.name: rumour that
examples: There’s an unsubstantiated rumour that Eddie is bankrupt.

children.name: it’s only a rumour
examples: I don’t think he’s going to resign. It’s only a rumour.

children.name: rumour has it thatthere is a rumour that
examples: Rumour has it that there will be major job cuts in the new year.

children.name: gossip
children.definition: information that is passed from one person to another about other people’s behaviour and private lives, often including unkind or untrue remarks : chuyện ngồi lê đôi mách, chuyện tầm phào

children.name: the latest gossip
examples: Annie usually has all the latest gossip.

children.name: juicy gossip
children.definition: interesting gossip
examples: He said that he had some especially juicy gossip to tell us.

children.name: hot gossip
children.definition: interesting gossip
examples: What’s the latest hot gossip going round at work then?

children.name: idle gossip
children.definition: gossip not based on facts
examples: She had no time for idle gossip.

children.name: common gossip
children.definition: gossip that everyone knows about
examples: Rumours about her affairs had become common gossip.

children.name: office gossip
examples: He told her a few bits of office gossip which he though might interest her.

children.name: village gossip
examples: BrE: She knew from village gossip how Harry had treated his first wife.

children.name: malicious gossip
children.definition: unkind gossip that is likely to upset someone
examples: Has someone been spreading malicious gossip?

children.name: a piece of gossip
examples: I’ve got an interesting piece of gossip which might interest you.

children.name: be the subject of gossip
children.definition: be talked about
examples: His close friendship with Carol was the subject of gossip.

children.name: exchange gossip
children.definition: talk about other people and their private lives with someone
examples: They used to meet up and exchange gossip.

children.name: hear gossip
examples: Have you heard the latest gossip about Steve?

children.name: listen to gossip
examples: He was always willing to listen to gossip.

children.name: spread gossip
examples: Someone’s been spreading gossip about Lucy and Ian.

children.name: gossip goes around
children.definition: it is told by one person to another
examples: It was a small village, and any gossip went around very quickly.

children.name: gossip about
examples: Here’s an interesting piece of gossip about Mrs Smith.

children.name: gossip columnpart of a newspaper that contains gossip about famous people
examples: Recently her name has showed up a lot in gossip columns.

children.name: talk
children.definition: information or news that people talk about and hear about a lot, but that is not official, especially about their sexual relationships: những cuộc nói chuyện, đồn đoán
examples: In those days there was always talk if two people lived together without being married.
talk of
Tickets sold so quickly there’s talk of a second concert.
talk of doing sth
the administration’s talk of reducing weapons
talk that
There’s talk that she’s difficult to work with.
just/only talka rumour that is unlikely to be true chỉ là đồn đại
‘They say he’s having an affair with a colleague at work.’ ‘That’s just talk.’
It’s just talk. He’ll never do it.

children.name: hearsay
children.definition: sth that you have heard from someone sb, but cannot prove whether it is true or untrue – often used in legal contexts : lời đồn thổi
examples: All the accounts were based on hearsay rather than eye-witness reports.
All the accounts were based on hearsay rather than eye-witness reports.
Judge Wagenbach ruled that the statement was inadmissible as evidence, after Mr. Lamb’s attourney argued that it was hearsay.

children.name: rely on hearsaytin vào lời đồn
examples: A factual book is a lot better than relying on hearsay from friends.

children.name: hearsay evidenceevidence given in a court of law by someone who did not directly see something happen chứng cứ do lời đồn đại
examples: The court is not allowed to admit hearsay evidence.

children.name: hear sth on the grapevine
children.definition: hear sth on/through the grapevine if you hear some news or information on or through the grapevine, sb else tells it to you unofficially, often in conversation: nghe người ta đồn

children.name: ‘Who told you I was moving house?’ ‘Oh, I just heard it on the grapevine.’
examples: Freddie was distressed when, through the grapevine, he heard of Liza’s marriage.
I heard on the grapevinethathe was leaving - is it true?

children.name: the school/hospital/industry etc grapevine
examples: According to the high-school grapevine, Kelly wants me to ask her out on a date.

children.name: rumoured
children.definition: British English,rumoredAmerican English if sb or sth is rumoured to be doing something, be happening, be in a particular condition etc, that is what you have heard people saying: bị, được đồn rằng

children.name: it is rumoured that
examples: It was rumoured that Johnson had been poisoned.

children.name: be rumoured to be
examples: She was rumoured to be a millionaire.

children.name: a young manwidely rumouredto be her lover
examples: It’s a five star hotel and rumored to be the best in Europe.
The hospital is rumoured to be heading for closure, after the government’s announcement on cuts.

children.name: reportedly
children.definition: according to what many people say : theo như đưa tin
examples: Her husband’s assets are reportedly worth over $15 million.
New York is reportedly a very exciting place to live.
